title: Nada Farhoud: New CITES animal export ban may not be enough to protect wildlife
text:

Thirty-five young elephants are to be flown from Zimbabwe to zoos in China despite a ban on such captures and exports.

The animals, some as young as two, are believed to have been forcibly separated from their parents in the wild and have been at the centre of a legal battle since footage of them being held in pens in the Hwange National Park emerged in February.

Conservationists say calves can be entirely dependent on their mothers for emotional and physical support until they are five.

Others can still be taking their mother’s milk until they are 10 or another sibling is born.

It was thought their fate was saved when the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), the organisation that sets worldwide rules on the sale of wild animals and their products, voted to stop these captures and exports.

But as the ban doesn’t take effect until the end of November, sources now say Zimbabwe Parks are gearing up to export the elephants in that small window of time.

News of the imminent export comes two years after 31 calves were flown to China, creating an international outcry.

Hwange National Park is also the site of the killing of Cecil the lion in 2015 by an American trophy hunter.

In the past few years, Zimbabwe has made £2million from the sale of 97 elephants to zoos, parks and other tourist attractions in China and Dubai in the United Arab Emirates.

And more deals are in the pipeline because Zimbabwe has announced it will sell the creatures “to anyone”.

The trade is cruel and ­repugnant but it provides welcome income for a country where a third of the 16 million population survive on food aid.

Drought has hit hard and inflation is the second highest in the world, after Venezuela.

Ignoring the ruling could violate Zimbabwean and international animal welfare regulations.

But the question now is whether the welfare of these animals takes priority over a country where much of the ­population is starving – and whether the West should tell Africa what to do.
description: A new ban on capture and export of wildlife doesn't take effect until the end of November, so unscrupulous animal dealers are taking full advantage of the time left to ply their trade
